title: Under the hood: The chemistry of cars - Cynthia Chubbuck

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the cooling system in a car engine?

options.label: B
options.text: To absorb, transport, and dissipate heat

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the engine's fuel efficiency

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the engine's noise pollution

multiple-choice.question: Why is water not an ideal choice for a car's cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: It has a low specific heat

options.label: B
options.text: It has a high boiling point

options.label: C
options.text: It expands as it freezes and has a relatively low boiling point

multiple-choice.question: What is a solution, in the context of chemistry?

options.label: A
options.text: A heterogeneous mixture of two or more substances

options.label: B
options.text: A homogeneous mixture consisting of a solute and a solvent

options.label: C
options.text: A pure substance with a fixed composition

options.label: D
options.text: A mixture of two or more elements

multiple-choice.question: What are colligative properties, and how do they relate to solutions?

options.label: A
options.text: Colligative properties are the properties of a solution that remain the same regardless of the proportion of solute present

options.label: B
options.text: Colligative properties are the properties of a solution that differ depending on the proportion of solute present

options.label: C
options.text: Colligative properties are the properties of a pure substance that are affected by the presence of a solute

options.label: D
options.text: Colligative properties are the properties of a solution that are independent of the solute's concentration

multiple-choice.question: Why does the presence of solute particles affect the freezing point of a solution?

options.label: A
options.text: The solute particles increase the attractive forces between the molecules

options.label: B
options.text: The solute particles decrease the attractive forces between the molecules

options.label: C
options.text: The solute particles get in the way of the attractive forces between the molecules

options.label: D
options.text: The solute particles have no effect on the attractive forces between the molecules

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of solute particles on the boiling point of a solution?

options.label: A
options.text: The solute particles decrease the boiling point

options.label: B
options.text: The solute particles increase the boiling point

options.label: C
options.text: The solute particles have no effect on the boiling point

options.label: D
options.text: The solute particles decrease the vapor pressure

multiple-choice.question: What is the commonly used solution for a car's cooling system, and what are its freezing and boiling points?

options.label: A
options.text: A 50/50 mixture of ethylene glycol and water, freezing at -12.9°C and boiling at 100°C

options.label: B
options.text: A 50/50 mixture of ethylene glycol and water, freezing at -37°C and boiling at 106°C

options.label: C
options.text: A 70/30 mixture of ethylene glycol and water, freezing at -55°C and boiling at 113°C

options.label: D
options.text: A 30/70 mixture of ethylene glycol and water, freezing at -20°C and boiling at 120°C

multiple-choice.question: Why is it not recommended to use a higher proportion of ethylene glycol in the cooling system?

options.label: A
options.text: It would decrease the freezing point and increase the boiling point

options.label: B
options.text: It would increase the freezing point and decrease the boiling point

options.label: C
options.text: It would make the solution more corrosive

options.label: D
options.text: The properties of the solution would head towards the properties of ethylene glycol, which freezes at a higher temperature

multiple-choice.question: What are the necessary properties of an effective and safe engine coolant?

options.label: A
options.text: High specific heat, high freezing point, and low boiling point

options.label: B
options.text: Low specific heat, low freezing point, and high boiling point

options.label: C
options.text: High specific heat, low freezing point, and high boiling point

options.label: D
options.text: Low specific heat, high freezing point, and low boiling point

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary advantage of creating a solution for the cooling system instead of searching for a perfect liquid?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows for a wider range of temperatures

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the engine's fuel efficiency

options.label: C
options.text: It reduces the engine's noise pollution

options.label: D
options.text: It enables the creation of a customized solution with desired properties

title: How playing an instrument benefits your brain - Anita Collins

multiple-choice.question: What happens in a musician's brain when they pick up their instrument?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain goes into a dormant state

options.label: B
options.text: A single area of the brain is activated

options.label: C
options.text: Fireworks go off all over the brain with multiple areas being activated

multiple-choice.question: How have neuroscientists made breakthroughs in understanding how our brains work?

options.label: B
options.text: By monitoring brains in real-time with instruments like fMRI and PET scanners

options.label: C
options.text: Through the study of animal behavior

multiple-choice.question: What happens when researchers get participants to listen to music?

options.label: A
options.text: A single area of the brain is activated

options.label: B
options.text: Multiple areas of the brain are activated, processing different elements of music

options.label: D
options.text: No change is observed in brain activity

multiple-choice.question: What is playing music equivalent to in terms of brain activity?
Which areas of the brain are especially engaged when playing a musical instrument?
What is the main difference between listening to music and playing it in terms of brain activity?

options.label: A
options.text: Listening to music requires fine motor skills

options.label: B
options.text: Playing music requires fine motor skills

options.label: C
options.text: Listening to music engages the linguistic and mathematical precision

options.label: D
options.text: Playing music only engages the right hemisphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of playing music on the brain's corpus callosum?

options.label: A
options.text: It decreases the volume and activity

options.label: B
options.text: It increases the volume and activity

options.label: D
options.text: It only affects the left hemisphere

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of musicians having higher levels of executive function?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only solve problems creatively

options.label: B
options.text: They can only solve problems effectively

options.label: C
options.text: They can solve problems more effectively and creatively

options.label: D
options.text: They have no advantage in problem-solving

multiple-choice.question: How do musicians exhibit enhanced memory functions?

options.label: A
options.text: By creating, storing, and retrieving memories slowly

options.label: B
options.text: By creating, storing, and retrieving memories more quickly and efficiently

options.label: C
options.text: By only using one tag for each memory

options.label: D
options.text: By not using tags for memories

multiple-choice.question: What have randomized studies found about the effects of music learning on brain areas?

options.label: A
options.text: It has no effect on brain areas

options.label: B
options.text: It only enhances one brain area

options.label: D
options.text: It decreases activity in brain areas

title: What happens when you get heat stroke? - Douglas J. Casa

multiple-choice.question: What event was 16-year-old Douglas Casa participating in when he suffered an exertional heat stroke in 1985?

options.label: B
options.text: The Empire State Games 10,000 meter track race

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary cause of exertional heat stroke?
What percentage of energy used during exercise is transformed into heat?
What is the primary criterion for diagnosing an exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: A core body temperature greater than 38 degrees Celsius

options.label: B
options.text: A core body temperature greater than 40 degrees Celsius

multiple-choice.question: What is the most feasible and accurate way to assess core body temperature in cases of suspected exertional heat stroke?
What is the recommended treatment approach for exertional heat stroke?

options.label: C
options.text: Call emergency services, but do not initiate cooling

options.label: D
options.text: Initiate cooling only after emergency personnel arrive

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended method for rapid cooling in cases of exertional heat stroke?

options.label: A
options.text: Placing the victim in an ice water tub while stirring the water and monitoring vitals

options.label: B
options.text: Dousing the victim in hot water

options.label: C
options.text: Applying dry towels over the entire body

options.label: D
options.text: Using a fan to circulate air

multiple-choice.question: At what core temperature should cooling be stopped if medical staff are available on site?
According to the transcript, what is the survival rate for exertional heat stroke with proper care?
Who wrote about exertional heat stroke in 1859, stating that "it strikes down its victim with his full armor on"?

title: A giant bubble for debate - Liz Diller

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

title: Music and emotion through time - Michael Tilson Thomas

multiple-choice.question: The speaker's father, Ted, was a self-taught illustrator and musician who didn't read notes and was hearing-impaired, yet he had a profound understanding of music. What was his approach to music?

options.label: A
options.text: He focused on the technical aspects of music.

options.label: B
options.text: He emphasized the emotional and expressive qualities of music.

options.label: C
options.text: He only listened to classical music.

options.label: D
options.text: He didn't appreciate music at all.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what are the two essential things that matter in music?
The speaker mentions that classical music is an unbroken living tradition that spans over a thousand years. What is the raw material of classical music?
How did the development of notation change music?

options.label: A
options.text: It limited the creativity of musicians.

options.label: B
options.text: It enabled musicians to imagine music on a much vaster scale.

options.label: C
options.text: It made music more accessible to the general public.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to the decline of classical music.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between an improviser and a composer?

options.label: A
options.text: An improviser creates music spontaneously, while a composer plans and structures their music.

options.label: B
options.text: An improviser only plays jazz, while a composer only writes classical music.

options.label: C
options.text: An improviser is more creative than a composer.

options.label: D
options.text: A composer is more skilled than an improviser.

multiple-choice.question: In the early centuries of classical music, what was the primary purpose of music?
What was the significant development in music around 1600?
According to the speaker, what is the difference between a major and minor chord?

options.label: A
options.text: A major chord has more notes than a minor chord.

options.label: B
options.text: A minor chord is sadder than a major chord.

options.label: C
options.text: The difference lies in the vibrations per second of the notes.

options.label: D
options.text: A major chord is more complex than a minor chord.

multiple-choice.question: How has technology changed the way we experience music?

options.label: A
options.text: It has made music more inaccessible.

options.label: B
options.text: It has limited the types of music we can listen to.

options.label: C
options.text: It has democratized music and made it more widely available.

options.label: D
options.text: It has led to the decline of classical music.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main concern when it comes to music?

options.label: A
options.text: That people are not listening to enough classical music.

options.label: B
options.text: That music is not being passed on to future generations.

options.label: D
options.text: That people are not taking music seriously enough.

multiple-choice.question: What were the two dreams of the speaker when he was growing up in Montana?

options.label: B
options.text: To be a paleontologist and have a pet dinosaur

options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: C

title: It's a church. It's a mosque. It's Hagia Sophia. - Kelly Wall

multiple-choice.question: In what year was the city where Hagia Sophia stands founded by Greek colonists?
What was the name of the first church built in the location of Hagia Sophia in the fourth century?

What is the name of the sultan who rededicated Hagia Sophia to Allah and proclaimed it the new imperial mosque?

title: Inside the ant colony - Deborah M. Gordon

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary way in which ants divide resources, organize major efforts, and distribute labor efficiently within their colonies?
What happens to the males after mating in many ant species?

options.label: B
options.text: They care for the queen and her eggs

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of fertilized eggs in an ant colony?
How do worker ants decide what to do and when?
What is the primary way in which ants explore large areas?

options.label: C
options.text: By changing their movement patterns based on individual interactions

multiple-choice.question: What happens when two ants meet and sense each other by touching antennae?

options.label: B
options.text: They respond by moving in more convoluted, random paths

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the pheromone trail left by ants when they find food?

options.label: C
options.text: To recruit other ants to follow the trail

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the pheromone trail when the food in a spot is depleted?

options.label: A
options.text: The ants continue to mark the trail

options.label: B
options.text: The scent dissipates and ants are no longer attracted to that path

options.label: C
options.text: The ants establish a new colony

options.label: D
options.text: The ants forage for food in a different area

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the practical applications of the methods used by ants to search and retrieve food?

options.label: B
options.text: Solving the famous traveling salesman problem

options.label: C
options.text: Enabling groups of robots to search a minefield or a burning building collectively

multiple-choice.question: What can be learned from observing the behavior of ants in empty spaces of various sizes?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of higher-level communication and planning

options.label: B
options.text: The effectiveness of simple, decentralized methods of search and retrieval

options.label: C
options.text: The role of males in establishing new colonies

title: How heavy is air? - Dan Quinn

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason we don't notice air as a fluid most of the time?

options.label: C
options.text: We commonly think of air as empty space

options.label: D
options.text: Air only flows at high altitudes

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many molecules are present in one cubic centimeter of air?
What is the force exerted by the swarm of air molecules when they run into things?
Why are we not immediately crushed by the weight of air in a typical school gym?

options.label: B
options.text: Most of the air is pressing on the floor and walls, and the part pressing on us is pushed back by the pressure inside us

options.label: C
options.text: The air is only present at high altitudes

options.label: D
options.text: The air is not a fluid

multiple-choice.question: What allows us to survive in the normal atmosphere?

options.label: A
options.text: The air pressure inside us is greater than the air pressure outside

options.label: B
options.text: The air pressure inside us is equal to the air pressure outside

options.label: C
options.text: The air pressure inside us is less than the air pressure outside

options.label: D
options.text: The air is not a fluid

multiple-choice.question: What happens when air pressure is not uniform?

options.label: C
options.text: The molecules push harder in one region of air than another, driving the air flow from the higher pressure region to the lower

options.label: D
options.text: The air is not a fluid

multiple-choice.question: What do we feel directly as a result of non-uniform air pressure?
How do we breathe in terms of air pressure?

options.label: A
options.text: By increasing the pressure in our lungs

options.label: B
options.text: By lowering the pressure in our lungs

options.label: C
options.text: By maintaining a constant pressure in our lungs

options.label: D
options.text: By eliminating air pressure in our lungs

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate number of air molecules in and around the human body compared to?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of grains of sand in a single beach

options.label: B
options.text: The number of stars in a single galaxy

options.label: C
options.text: The number of grains of sand in all the world's beaches and deserts, or the number of stars in the visible universe

options.label: D
options.text: The number of molecules in a single cubic centimeter of air

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, where is the vastness of the universe located in relation to us?

options.label: C
options.text: Right in front of us and inside us

What is the current conservation status of the cotton-top tamarin?

title: The quest to understand consciousness - Antonio Damasio

multiple-choice.question: What is the main topic of discussion in the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: The importance of sleep for brain function

options.label: B
options.text: The Wonder and Mystery of conscious Minds

options.label: C
options.text: The role of the brain stem in regulating body functions

options.label: D
options.text: The impact of culture on human behavior

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the "Wonder" of conscious Minds?

options.label: A
options.text: The ability to create art and music

options.label: B
options.text: The fact that we have a sense of self and existence

options.label: C
options.text: The capacity for language and communication

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to solve complex mathematical problems

multiple-choice.question: What is the "mystery" that the speaker refers to in the transcript?

options.label: C
options.text: The mechanism of how we make Consciousness in our brains

options.label: D
options.text: The secrets of the human genome

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between the grid of neurons and our mental experience?

options.label: A
options.text: There is no direct relationship between the two

options.label: B
options.text: The grid of neurons determines our mental experience

options.label: C
options.text: Our mental experience is independent of the grid of neurons

options.label: D
options.text: A small change in the grid of neurons can result in a significant change in our mental experience

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the brain stem in generating a conscious mind?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides the grounding for the self through the mapping of the body's interior

options.label: B
options.text: It is responsible for the creation of mental images

options.label: C
options.text: It regulates body functions such as heart rate and blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: It is involved in the processing of sensory information

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the autobiographical self?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of self that is shared with many other species

options.label: B
options.text: A self that is built on the basis of past memories and memories of the plans that we have made

options.label: C
options.text: A self that is independent of the brain stem and cerebellum

options.label: D
options.text: A self that is responsible for regulating body functions

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the brain stem being shared with other species?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that other species do not have conscious Minds

options.label: B
options.text: It implies that the brain stem is not important for conscious Minds

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that other species may have conscious Minds similar to ours

options.label: D
options.text: It implies that the cerebellum is more important for conscious Minds

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why should we care about understanding how the brain works?

options.label: A
options.text: So that we can develop new technologies

options.label: B
options.text: So that we can understand society and culture

options.label: C
options.text: So that we can develop new treatments for diseases such as depression and Alzheimer's

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the cerebellum and the brain stem in generating a conscious mind?

options.label: A
options.text: The cerebellum is responsible for generating the self, while the brain stem is responsible for regulating body functions

options.label: B
options.text: The brain stem provides the grounding for the self, while the cerebellum provides the contents of our minds

options.label: C
options.text: The cerebellum and brain stem work together to regulate body functions

options.label: D
options.text: The cerebellum and brain stem are not connected in generating a conscious mind

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the role of culture in shaping our minds?

options.label: A
options.text: Culture has no impact on our minds

options.label: C
options.text: Culture develops in collectives of human beings and shapes our autobiographical self

options.label: D
options.text: Culture is only important for language and communication

title: Less stuff, more happiness - Graham Hill

title: Doodlers, unite! - Sunni Brown

options.label: D
options.text: A person who is good at problem-solving.

options.label: B
options.text: To waste time and do nothing.

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: People who doodle retain more information than those who don't.

options.label: D
options.text: There is no effect on information retention.

options.label: C
options.text: It engages all four learning modalities simultaneously.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no contribution to the learning process.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That children exhibit the same evolution and visual logic as they grow, across space and time.

options.label: D
options.text: That children do not exhibit any evolution and visual logic as they grow.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a famous architect who used doodling as a precursor to a major design?
According to the speaker, where should doodling be leveraged?

options.label: C
options.text: In situations where information density is very high and the need for processing that information is very high.

options.label: D
options.text: Nowhere, it's a waste of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's main point about doodling?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a waste of time and should be eradicated from classrooms and boardrooms.

options.label: B
options.text: It's only useful for people with artistic skills.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a powerful tool that should be leveraged in situations where information density is high.
